# Sri Ramakrishna's Teachings on God-Centered Living

## The Uncompromising Focus on God

Sri Ramakrishna, the 19th-century Indian mystic, embodied an extraordinary intensity in his spiritual practice—one that tolerated no distraction from thoughts of God. This single-minded devotion manifested in ways that might seem extreme to modern sensibilities, yet reveal profound spiritual truths about the nature of divine focus.

### The Slapping Incidents

Two remarkable stories illustrate Sri Ramakrishna's intolerance for worldly distractions during spiritual practice:

He once famously—or infamously—slapped Rani Rashmoni, the wealthy patron and owner of the Kali temple where he served as a humble priest. She had been sitting before the deity Kali while thinking about worldly matters. Sri Ramakrishna, possessing the ability to read minds, detected her distraction immediately. To her credit, Rani Rashmoni possessed the spiritual maturity to understand his intent rather than taking offense.

On another occasion, he slapped a great scholar who sat on the banks of the Ganga telling his beads while his mind wandered elsewhere. The spiritual teacher's intolerance for divided attention was absolute, regardless of the person's social status or scholarly achievements.

As one swami humorously noted, "Thank God he is not physically around anymore—otherwise our cheeks would always be red and stinging from being slapped for thinking about something other than God."

### A Universal Spiritual Principle

This intense focus on the divine isn't unique to Hindu spirituality. A fascinating parallel emerges from Islamic tradition, as shared by an Iraqi doctor who became a monk in the Ramakrishna Order while maintaining his Muslim faith.

This remarkable individual—who would wash his hands in Ganga water before reading the Quran—shared stories about Prophet Muhammad's companion Omar. When the Prophet instituted the five daily prayers, including the very early morning prayer, Omar would go through the streets with a tree branch, literally whipping people awake to ensure they attended prayers. The similarity to Sri Ramakrishna's approach is striking: both recognized that spiritual practice requires undivided attention.

When asked how he reconciled his devotion to both Islam and Sri Ramakrishna, this Muslim monk offered a profound perspective: "I consider that Prophet Muhammad was also an avatar of Mother Kali." For him, the Divine Mother manifested through different prophets and incarnations across traditions.

## The Pain of Worldly Conversation

Sri Ramakrishna himself became alarmed by his tendency to physically strike those whose minds wandered from God. He prayed fervently to the Divine Mother: "Let me stop this. Why is my nature becoming like this?" After intense prayer, this particular manifestation of his spiritual intensity subsided.

What remained, however, was his profound discomfort with worldly conversation. As recorded on page 119 of The Gospel of Sri Ramakrishna, dated October 16, 1882:

**"When one gets into such a state of mind, one doesn't enjoy any conversation but that about God. I used to weep when I heard people talk about worldly matters."**

During a pilgrimage to Benares, while staying at a wealthy devotee's house, Sri Ramakrishna found himself in a drawing room conversation about business losses and other worldly concerns. He wept bitterly and prayed to the Divine Mother: "Mother, where have you brought me? I was much better off in the temple garden at Dakshineswar. Here I am at a place where I must hear about lust and gold."

### The Constant God-Centered Atmosphere

Throughout the Gospel of Sri Ramakrishna, we see that conversations—even during light moments, jokes, and teasing—always pointed back toward God. This doesn't mean every sentence literally mentioned God, but that everything remained centered around spiritual consciousness.

Swami Vivekananda once joked about Sri Ramakrishna years after the master's passing. When a young devotee objected, "You're joking about Sri Ramakrishna!" Vivekananda replied, "Yes—whom should I joke about, you?" Even in humor, the spiritual focus remained paramount.

## The Danger of Worldly Talk

Sri Ramakrishna couldn't tolerate conversations about money or worldly frivolities—not because he was a dry moralist, but because such talk extinguished the divine joy that comes from God-consciousness. Around him, there was "like a festival of joy all the time," but this joy depended on maintaining spiritual elevation.

### The Practical Wisdom of Spiritual Teachers

This understanding appears across spiritual traditions. One great Himalayan monk, a strict non-dualist, would immediately begin talking about Brahman to visitors before they could initiate worldly conversation. When asked why, he explained that his guru had instructed him: "When worldly people visit you, don't allow them to talk. Even before they start talking about anything, start talking about Brahman, about God—otherwise they'll talk about the world and drag the conversation down."

The author experienced this directly during his first meeting with this Himalayan monk: "The moment I bowed down, he started talking about the highest Vedanta about the nature of one's real self... I had not even said anything. After he had finished—just a few minutes—I felt there's nothing more to be said." The impact lasted 16 years, with the teachings remaining vividly clear in memory.

Another senior swami advised monks to avoid "the three kinds of politics: international politics, national politics, and ashram politics."

### Transformative Training

Swami Smaranananda, now vice president of the Ramakrishna Order, shared a telling story from his early days as a brahmachari. He served as attendant to an elderly swami who was unwell. One evening after arati, other monks invited him for tea and puffed rice. He asked permission from the elderly swami, who said nothing. The next day, when the young brahmachari didn't go for tea, the swami asked why not. "I don't like it," he replied. The elderly swami heaved a sigh of relief and said, "You are saved."

Even small distractions—like tea and casual conversation after evening prayers—could diminish spiritual intensity. The most profound teaching often came at unexpected moments. Late at night, when the nearly blind elderly swami needed bathroom assistance, he would hold onto his young attendant's shoulder and say, "Understand this well—the Atman is not the five sheaths of the body." At 1:30 or 2:00 AM, while the young novice stood literally falling asleep, the teaching continued. As Swami Smaranananda explained: "These things are real to them, and they are so amazing for them, and they know it can become real for us and it will save our lives—it will change our lives forever. That's why they're so eager for us to see it."

## The Joy of God-Centered Living

The contrast between worldly conversation and God-centered living becomes vividly apparent in descriptions of devotional gatherings around Sri Ramakrishna.

### Ecstatic Music Sessions

One evening, Narendra (later Swami Vivekananda) and other devotees sang devotional songs, accompanied by drums and cymbals. They sang:

**"Meditate, O my mind, on the Lord Hari, the stainless One, pure Spirit through and through. How peerless is the light that in Him shines! How so bewitching is His wondrous form! How dear is He to all His devotees!"**

Narendra sang with a beaming face: **"Chant the sweet name of God till in your heart the nectar overflows. Drink of it ceaselessly and share it with all."**

The devotees moved round and round the master as they sang: **"Immerse yourself forevermore, O mind, in Him who is pure knowledge and pure bliss."**

Sri Ramakrishna's joy became so overwhelming that he held Narendra in his arms for a long time, saying, "You have made us so happy today." That night, "the floodgate of the master's heart was open so wide that he could hardly contain himself for joy." Intoxicated with divine love, he paced the verandah, talking to the Divine Mother and declaring, "What can you do to me?"—perhaps indicating that Maya was helpless before one who had the Divine Mother as support.

### The Radiance of Divine Joy

This episode reveals "the sheer joy which shines forth—the feeling of joy in the presence of God, singing the name of God, in chanting, in music, in dance, in laughter." All of it centered on "God and God only." Worldliness carefully avoided because it destroys this elevated state—"it pulls us down from there."

When spiritual teaching lacks this core of love and joy, it becomes "dry and boring," inspiring neither practitioners nor observers. The most effective spiritual teachers radiate a palpable joy that creates what might be called "holy envy"—not the destructive jealousy of ego, but the inspiring thought: "I wish I could have some of that."

In the presence of such spiritually advanced people, "your mind is uplifted effortlessly." With particularly powerful individuals, "the circle of influence is quite large—it could be the entire ashram. You can palpably feel the difference when such a great one is present."

## The Trap of Critical Conversation

A revealing incident demonstrates Sri Ramakrishna's attitude toward another common type of unproductive conversation: criticism of others.

### The Schoolboys Discussion

After an evening meal, Narendra (then about 19) and M (a 28-year-old schoolteacher) began discussing the moral decline of contemporary youth:

Narendra observed: "From my experience, I feel that they are going to the dogs. They smoke cigarettes, indulge in frivolous talk, enjoy foolishness, play truant, and do everything of that sort. I've even seen them visiting questionable places."

M responded: "I didn't notice such things during our student days."

Narendra countered: "Perhaps you didn't mix with the students intimately. I have even seen them talking with people of immoral character. Perhaps they are on terms of intimacy with them."

When Sri Ramakrishna joined them and asked what they were discussing, Narendra explained they'd been talking about the poor conduct of modern students. The master became grave and said to M rather seriously:

**"This kind of conversation is not good. It isn't desirable to indulge in any talk but talk of God. You are their senior and you are intelligent. You should not have encouraged them to talk about such matters."**

### The Universal Tendency to Criticize

This pattern of criticizing younger generations appears universal. As the speaker noted: "This is more than 150 years ago. So they're saying the same thing." If we go back hundreds of years, we find similar discussions among devotees lamenting how things were better in old times.

Swami Bhuteshananda, the 12th president of the Ramakrishna Order, would humorously imitate elderly monks shaking their heads dolefully: "In our time it wasn't so bad. These young boys—they're going to go to ruin." Every generation tends to believe they lived in a golden age while the new generation is awful.

Sri Ramakrishna immediately disapproved of such talk because criticism "is a negative thing. It does no good to anybody else, and it damages your own purity of mind, the elevation of mind, and it poisons the atmosphere around."

Swami Vivekananda himself—who participated in this criticism—later advised: "Never criticize. Lend a helping hand if you can. If you cannot, bow down from a distance, but don't criticize. It hurts—it wounds a person's feelings." Mark Twain captured the underlying motivation perfectly: "I have seen that those who claim to be fond of the brutal truth are often fond of brutality more than the truth."

## The Balance of Compassion and Discipline

While Sri Ramakrishna emphasized gentle God-centered conversation, this doesn't mean spiritual teachers never employ firmness. The key distinction lies in the motivation behind the strictness.

### Love Behind the Sternness

Some spiritual teachers appear harsh, but their strictness comes from genuine concern for others' wellbeing. As Swami Vivekananda once said while scolding a worker: "For these fellows, I am perfectly capable of giving up my life for them. For their own good, if necessary, I'm willing to hang them from the nearest tree." The same person willing to give severe correction was also willing to sacrifice everything for those same people.

A beautiful story illustrates this compassionate firmness:

A monk was accused of wrongdoing and faced expulsion from the order. Swami Brahmananda, the order's president, told the senior monks: "On the other side of the Ganga, make a little hut. In that hut, I will go and live with that monk. You have your Belur Math, you have your monasteries, you have all this organization—everything. You stay here. He has nobody else in the world, so I'll go and live with him."

This profound gesture—the president willing to leave the entire organization to accompany an expelled monk—so moved the senior monks that they withdrew the expulsion order. Such powerful compassion can be profoundly transformative.

Another example comes from the current president of the order, who as general secretary would sternly instruct novices about maintaining clean clothes. After considerable scolding, he once told a young monk: "Give me your clothes—I'll wash them and give them back to you." This combination of high standards and personal care created lasting impact.

## Practical Application for Householders

A legitimate question arises: How can those living in the world—with jobs, families, and worldly responsibilities—apply this teaching about avoiding worldly conversation?

### Creating Spiritual Boundaries

The solution lies in establishing clear boundaries around specific places and times:

**Place:** Designate certain areas as exclusively for spiritual practice. "This is the place where I sit and meditate. Nothing else is allowed here. Even if your son or daughter wants to come and study there—no. This place is only meant for meditation, prayer, devotional songs, devotional reading, and that's it."

**Time:** "Put a circle around times. This is the time nobody in the world will disturb me. Yes, I am there to take care of all of you. I'm going to deal with all of your problems. I'm there. I've been here for years as father, mother, grandfather, grandmother—whoever you are. I'm going to deal with all of that. But this is time for I and God. No admittance to the world."

This protection is essential because if worldly concerns "engulf you, you are no use to either yourself or to the world also. If you are upset, desirous, grasping, greedy, annoyed, irritated—what good are you to anybody else? You're no good to yourself or to anybody else. If you are calm and centered and your mind is set on higher things, your very presence will be a blessing to others."

### Understanding the Defects of Worldliness

Why exactly does Sri Ramakrishna emphasize avoiding worldly conversation? Three key reasons emerge:

**1. Ephemerality:** Worldly matters are impermanent. "The people—people don't want to confront the transience, the ephemerality, the impermanence of life." Sri Ramakrishna, like the Buddha, stressed impermanence because it's a fact anyone can grasp without philosophical training. "All of us are growing older day by day, and especially when you look back upon life, 20-30-40 years have passed in a twinkling." When we consider this reality, conversations about "the best deals I got on Black Friday" or salacious gossip seem trivial compared to eternal truths.

**2. Deep Unsatisfaction:** Worldly pleasures ultimately fail to satisfy. Compare the joy of Sri Ramakrishna's devotees—sustained throughout their lives—with the temporary thrill of worldly entertainment. "If you keep doing it one month, one year, ten years, twenty years, thirty years—there's something wrong there." The psychologist Mihaly Csikszentmihalyi observes that some pleasures leave us feeling more integrated and elevated, while others leave us feeling worse—disintegrated and lowered.

**3. Binding Nature:** Worldly pursuits set in motion "subtle forces" that bind us. "Once we pursue these things, sense pleasures of any kind, you'll see that we are setting into motion subtle forces... Later when we want to break free of them, we find it very difficult to break free."

### Redirecting Energy to Spiritual Practice

When worldly interests diminish through spiritual practice, the saved time and energy should be redirected toward the four yogas:

**1. Jnana Yoga** - Knowledge of the self and reality: "Who am I actually? What am I? That is the key—the billion-dollar question which we ignore completely."

**2. Raja Yoga** - Training of attention: "Modern positive psychologists will wholeheartedly agree that this is a very critical issue."

**3. Bhakti Yoga** - Love of God and humanity: "This is the higher love, the altruistic love."

**4. Karma Yoga** - Expression in service: "Wherever you are, whatever field we are in, we can be of service to others."

## Dealing with Unpleasant Situations

A practical question arises: How do we maintain spiritual focus in unpleasant circumstances or with difficult people?

### Non-Reaction and Divine Perspective

Eleanor Roosevelt offered wisdom applicable here: "No one can hurt you without your own consent." When someone behaves unpleasantly toward us, the actual hurt occurs when our mind cooperates with that negativity. The solution involves training the mind "first of all not to take the side of the person who is nasty or being unpleasant. Your mind should be on your side."

The Buddha demonstrated this when someone abused him during his alms round. The Buddha responded: "You have given these to me—this abuse and this ridicule. I do not accept it. So it returns back to you." Spiritual strength comes from being "well settled and firm in your spiritual conviction" rather than cooperating with negativity.

Seeing divinity in unpleasant situations isn't sentimental imagination but recognizing the underlying reality: "Doesn't matter if the person is being nasty to me or good to me. Still such—because isn't existence-consciousness-bliss appearing in this particular name and form? Name and form are not important."

### Developing Compassion

When hurt by others, we can cultivate compassion by recognizing: "That feeling—the way I am hurt by these things—that other person also will get hurt. They are just like me. What hurts me hurts them also. What gives me joy and peace of mind gives them joy and peace of mind also."

The Buddhist sage Shantideva presents a powerful argument in Bodhicharyavatara: "We want to remove pain and we want to increase joy, but the pain is the same pain everywhere. The joy is exactly like that everywhere. It's only our delusion of the ego—my joy, my pain... Why not reduce pain everywhere and increase joy everywhere? And it'll work for you immediately—it'll reduce your own pain, increase your own joy."

## Conclusion: The Transformative Power of God-Centered Living

Sri Ramakrishna's teachings on maintaining God-centered conversation and avoiding worldly talk aren't about dry moralizing but about preserving the incredible joy that comes from divine consciousness. The stories of ecstatic singing, dancing, and spiritual fellowship around the master reveal a quality of joy that sustained his disciples throughout their lives—transforming them into spiritual giants who carried his message worldwide.

The practical application for modern seekers involves creating protected spaces and times for spiritual practice while understanding why worldly conversation diminishes our spiritual capacity. By redirecting our energy toward knowledge, meditation, love, and service—and developing compassion even in difficult circumstances—we can taste the profound joy that comes from keeping God at the center of our lives.

As the description of the devotees singing around Sri Ramakrishna illustrates: "On every side shine devotees like stars around the moon. Their friend the Lord all-merciful joyously plays with them." This vibrant, joyful spirituality—not dry moralizing—is what makes God-centered living so compelling and transformative.

Why exactly does Sri Ramakrishna emphasize avoiding worldly conversation? Three key reasons emerge:

**1. Ephemerality:** Worldly matters are impermanent. "The people—people don't want to confront the transience, the ephemerality, the impermanence of life." Sri Ramakrishna, like the Buddha, stressed impermanence because it's a fact anyone can grasp without philosophical training. "All of us are growing older day by day, and especially when you look back upon life, 20-30-40 years have passed in a twinkling." When we consider this reality, conversations about "the best deals I got on Black Friday" or salacious gossip seem trivial compared to eternal truths.

**2. Deep Unsatisfaction:** Worldly pleasures ultimately fail to satisfy. Compare the joy of Sri Ramakrishna's devotees—sustained throughout their lives—with the temporary thrill of worldly entertainment. "If you keep doing it one month, one year, ten years, twenty years, thirty years—there's something wrong there." The psychologist Mihaly Csikszentmihalyi observes that some pleasures leave us feeling more integrated and elevated, while others leave us feeling worse—disintegrated and lowered.

**3. Binding Nature:** Worldly pursuits set in motion "subtle forces" that bind us. "Once we pursue these things, sense pleasures of any kind, you'll see that we are setting into motion subtle forces... Later when we want to break free of them, we find it very difficult to break free."

### Redirecting Energy to Spiritual Practice

When worldly interests diminish through spiritual practice, the saved time and energy should be redirected toward the four yogas:

**1. Jnana Yoga** - Knowledge of the self and reality: "Who am I actually? What am I? That is the key—the billion-dollar question which we ignore completely."

**2. Raja Yoga** - Training of attention: "Modern positive psychologists will wholeheartedly agree that this is a very critical issue."

**3. Bhakti Yoga** - Love of God and humanity: "This is the higher love, the altruistic love."

**4. Karma Yoga** - Expression in service: "Wherever you are, whatever field we are in, we can be of service to others."

## Dealing with Unpleasant Situations

A practical question arises: How do we maintain spiritual focus in unpleasant circumstances or with difficult people?

### Non-Reaction and Divine Perspective

Eleanor Roosevelt offered wisdom applicable here: "No one can hurt you without your own consent." When someone behaves unpleasantly toward us, the actual hurt occurs when our mind cooperates with that negativity. The solution involves training the mind "first of all not to take the side of the person who is nasty or being unpleasant. Your mind should be on your side."

The Buddha demonstrated this when someone abused him during his alms round. The Buddha responded: "You have given these to me—this abuse and this ridicule. I do not accept it. So it returns back to you." Spiritual strength comes from being "well settled and firm in your spiritual conviction" rather than cooperating with negativity.

Seeing divinity in unpleasant situations isn't sentimental imagination but recognizing the underlying reality: "Doesn't matter if the person is being nasty to me or good to me. Still such—because isn't existence-consciousness-bliss appearing in this particular name and form? Name and form are not important."

### Developing Compassion

When hurt by others, we can cultivate compassion by recognizing: "That feeling—the way I am hurt by these things—that other person also will get hurt. They are just like me. What hurts me hurts them also. What gives me joy and peace of mind gives them joy and peace of mind also."

The Buddhist sage Shantideva presents a powerful argument in Bodhicharyavatara: "We want to remove pain and we want to increase joy, but the pain is the same pain everywhere. The joy is exactly like that everywhere. It's only our delusion of the ego—my joy, my pain... Why not reduce pain everywhere and increase joy everywhere? And it'll work for you immediately—it'll reduce your own pain, increase your own joy."

## Conclusion: The Transformative Power of God-Centered Living

Sri Ramakrishna's teachings on maintaining God-centered conversation and avoiding worldly talk aren't about dry moralizing but about preserving the incredible joy that comes from divine consciousness. The stories of ecstatic singing, dancing, and spiritual fellowship around the master reveal a quality of joy that sustained his disciples throughout their lives—transforming them into spiritual giants who carried his message worldwide.

The practical application for modern seekers involves creating protected spaces and times for spiritual practice while understanding why worldly conversation diminishes our spiritual capacity. By redirecting our energy toward knowledge, meditation, love, and service—and developing compassion even in difficult circumstances—we can taste the profound joy that comes from keeping God at the center of our lives.

As the description of the devotees singing around Sri Ramakrishna illustrates: "On every side shine devotees like stars around the moon. Their friend the Lord all-merciful joyously plays with them." This vibrant, joyful spirituality—not dry moralizing—is what makes God-centered living so compelling and transformative.
